"We aren't achieving world peace here, but it's nice to be recognized by the federal government as Hoosiers. It's not just a classic movie. It’s not just the nickname for IU athletics. It’s who we are."

I am very excited to share tomorrow's historic inaugural event with hundreds of Hoosiers who have made the trek to our nation's capital. It was great to see many of them in my office earlier today.

General James Mattis is an extraordinary public servant and an excellent fit to lead the Department of Defense. It was an honor to vote to confirm him as our country’s 26th Defense Secretary. As a fellow Marine, I’ve followed him closely over the years and have a full appreciation for his wide range of skills. From one Marine to another: Oorah!   I offered a few thoughts on this great leader ahead of last Friday’s vote. Take a look!

I'm thrilled to see Toyota Indiana investing in our state and in hardworking Hoosier families. The car manufacturer is investing $600 million dollars in the Princeton plant to add 400 new jobs and make technological improvements. The improvements relate to the plant's production of the Highlander mid-size SUV.

I was proud to join Senator Marco Rubio and John Cornyn in introducing the Iran Non-Nuclear Sanctions Act.   Iran remains a preeminent threat due to its continued support for terrorism and its aggressive development of ballistic missiles that threaten our allies, forward-deployed troops, and eventually our homeland.  This legislation would impose real consequences on Iran and make clear that the days when Tehran’s terrorist and ballistic missile activities elicited little more from Washington than a strong statement and a slap on the wrist are gone.

I'm fighting for opportunities to put children like Amori Curiel, a student in Indianapolis, in the best position to succeed. Her mom used the Indiana school choice program to help her daughter escape a harmful learning environment and enroll in a school where she is now thriving.  Amori's mother says, "I feel very fortunate. The children have changed a lot and they like the school very much."   American Federation for Children

Today is a day to celebrate life. We join our neighbors to pray for the lives of the unborn, the birth parents who choose life, and the moms and dads who welcome adopted children into their families.    It was a great privilege for my wife Jenny and me to help families navigate the adoption process by offering free legal services for loving, caring, Hoosiers who wanted to become parents. I also worked with a great organization, the Hannah House Maternity Home.  Their mission is to pray, care for, love and support women who need assistance during a difficult time in their lives. Nearly every parent we worked with – both birth parents and adopted parents – shared the desire to offer the best possible life for their child: they just wanted him or her to be loved and have every opportunity to succeed.    As a community, we are called to honor life and encourage all parents on this journey as well: let’s love them and support them. Their decision may lead the world to knowing the next great scientist, artist, teacher, athlete or perhaps just a loving neighbor who helps other parents navigate this very difficult decision some day as well.   #MarchforLife

Hoosiers who need assistance with casework, such as social security, Medicare, and Veterans Administration concerns can now reach my Constituent Services Centers in New Albany and Indianapolis.    You can find full contact information for all of my offices by visiting my website: young.senate.gov

Iran’s ballistic missile program threatens our forward deployed troops, our allies, and eventually our homeland. As they have done throughout our nation’s history, members of our armed forces are once again bravely serving and fighting overseas to keep us safe, and it is important for them and their families to know that Americans and their representatives in Congress stand with them.  In addition to providing our troops the necessary resources for victory, the best way for Congress to express that support is to consider and pass a well-formulated authorization of military force.
It was great to discuss a broad range of important issues at this week's Hoosier Huddle. Thank you to all of those who came out.

On January 28, President Trump directed his administration to develop a “comprehensive plan to defeat ISIS,” including a preliminary draft within 30 days.  Defense Secretary Jim Mattis reportedly briefed top officials this week on the preliminary plan.   When the Trump administration completes its plan, Congress will have another opportunity to finally fulfill its Constitutional responsibility to grant or withhold authority to conduct combat operations against ISIS.  As a new member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, I believe it is long past time for Congress to consider and pass an authorization for use of military force (AUMF) against ISIS and send a clear message to our troops in harm’s way that we support them and have their backs.      As they have done throughout our nation’s history, members of our armed forces are once again bravely serving and fighting overseas to keep us safe, and it is important for them and their families to know that Americans and their representatives in Congress stand with them.  In addition to providing our troops the necessary resources for victory, the best way for Congress to express that support is to consider and pass a well-formulated AUMF.  Article 1, Section 8 of the Constitution clearly states that Congress has the power “to declare war.”  Yet, two-and-a-half years after the U.S. began bombing ISIS—and with thousands of Americans already on the ground in Iraq and Syria—Congress has failed to exercise this fundamental Constitutional responsibility.   The American people have a right to expect better from Congress.  Undoubtedly, many in Congress, including members of both parties on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, have introduced legislation and made good faith efforts to pass an AUMF focused on ISIS.  Still, the simple fact remains that Congress as an institution has failed to fulfill its Constitutional responsibility.  We will soon have an opportunity to debate the President’s plan and to extend or withhold our authorization for its implementation.   More is at stake than an abstract legal requirement.   As students of history, our founders understood that the decision to go to war represented one of the gravest and most serious decisions any government faces.  To avoid foolish, hasty, unnecessary, or perpetual wars that tend to accrue debt and erode liberty, the founders wisely divided war powers between the legislative and executive branches of government.  While the founders clearly designated the President to serve as Commander-in-Chief, the founders granted to Congress an impressive list of enumerated powers related to war centering on the power to declare war.  The founders intended—and the Constitution demands—that Congress play a decisive role in the decision to go to war—not act as a rubber stamp or passive observer.  For much of American history, Congress took that Constitutional responsibility seriously.  According to the Congressional Research Service, since our nation’s founding, Congress has passed 11 separate formal declarations of war against foreign nations and at least 70 other statutory provisions authorizing the use of military forces for various purposes, including engaging in hostilities. Yet, since World War II, Congress has routinely waived its Constitutional duty to assert its explicit war powers.  Not surprisingly, Congressional inaction has resulted in a consolidation of war powers in the executive branch that many of our founding fathers would have found concerning and unhealthy for our republic.   There is little doubt that the President has the authority to utilize military force in short-term cases of immediate national emergency, but no reasonable definition of such an instance could or should include the engagement of U.S. military forces in protracted hostilities in foreign countries absent a declaration of war or authorization of Congress.  It is worth noting that the Obama administration urged Congress to pass an AUMF against ISIS but also argued that the 2001 and 2002 AUMFs provided the necessary legal authority for military operations, but it is past time to reassert Congress’s proper role in authorizing the use of military force against ISIS, an organization that didn’t even exist in 2001.   While these questions regarding the legal foundation for the war against ISIS demonstrate the need for a new AUMF, when one considers the courage and sacrifice of our service members and their families, the case for Congressional action and an AUMF focused on ISIS seems even clearer.  I recognize that members of Congress will have different views on the optimal nature of an AUMF focused on ISIS and that the details for a new AUMF will matter.  We should seek to build consensus and make principled compromises where possible, but we should move forward without delay.   An AUMF against ISIS would incentivize greater Congressional scrutiny and oversight of the executive branch’s strategy to defeat ISIS, establish greater accountability by Congress to the American people, and prevent a further dangerous erosion in the Congressional war powers that undercuts the ability of the American people to influence our nation’s decisions related to war and peace.    That is why today I introduced legislation in the Senate that would authorize the use of military force against ISIS and require the administration to submit to Congress a detailed strategy to defeat the terrorist organization.  I am ready to roll up my sleeves, analyze the Trump administration’s new plan, and take tough votes.  That is what my constituents expect, the Constitution demands, and our troops deserve.

Toured the JCC Indianapolis this morning. It's an important fixture in Indy. It's paramount that all our residents feel safe and secure in their daily lives and we will not tolerate hate toward the Jewish community or any of our fellow Hoosiers.

The very best athletes our country has to offer sacrifice every minute of their lives to fulfill their Olympic dreams. In turn, their parents trust that coaches and Olympic officials will safeguard their children and their dreams.   USA Gymnastics, among others, has not upheld its commitment to protecting our athletes. This horrifying pattern of seemingly turning a blind eye to sexual abuse is disgusting. It's imperative that we address this problem and create real enforcement mechanisms to ensure this vile activity ends.

We have a moral obligation to weigh in from time to time about issues pertaining to military force and when we send our young men and women into battle. To the extent we delegate that authority to the commander in chief, we act in a less than ethical and a less than constitutional fashion.   Our men and women in harm's way need to know that they have the support of their communities and elected officials back home. An authorization for use of military force (AUMF) is one way to show that.

From the Washington Post: "There is no 'traditional' 60-vote 'standard' or 'rule' for Supreme Court nominations, no matter how much or how often Democrats claim otherwise."  Democrats continue to threaten a filibuster based on a "precedent" that does not exist. Judge Gorsuch's judicial approach is mainstream and grounded in faithful obedience to the law.   He's not an activist or a legislator. But he understands his essential role in our Constitutional system. I can not think of a better candidate to replace Justice Scalia on the Supreme Court.

My statement on yesterday's military strikes in Syria:   “The international community has looked the other way for too long and has failed to act as Assad and Putin have deliberately and barbarically murdered innocent men, women, and children in Syria, and I applaud the Trump administration’s decision to take action.  Our men and women in uniform conducted yesterday’s strikes with professionalism and precision, and I join all Americans in expressing our gratitude to our service members,” said Senator Young.  Young continued, “After attending a briefing today with General Dunford, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, I am confident that the President will continue to receive sound advice from his impressive national security team.  Following these strikes, the administration should submit to Congress without delay a comprehensive, whole-of-government strategy—working with our international partners.  Our national security interests require that this strategy seeks to eliminate ISIS’s remaining safe haven in Syria, end the Syrian regime’s war on its own people, address the humanitarian crisis, and begin a political process that includes the departure of Assad and the establishment of an inclusive Syrian government.  Simultaneously, Congress finally should fulfill its Constitutional responsibility to consider and pass an appropriately crafted authorization for use of military force.”
Thanks to the 8th graders from St. Charles School in Bloomington for picking the sunny day to stop by the Capitol this week! Enjoy the rest of your trip and safe travels back home!

This morning, I spoke at Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division  to highlight the facility's importance as part of our nation's nuclear deterrence efforts.   The best way to keep our country safe from nuclear threats is to maintain an advanced deterrence. You can count on me to support the investments necessary to sustain and modernize our nation’s nuclear deterrent.

She delighted Late Show audiences with her guest appearances straight from her Carmel, Indiana kitchen, but she was just as beloved in the community she gave so much back to. She will be remembered fondly and missed greatly by those who knew her.

Today’s briefing at the White House underscored that North Korea’s nuclear and ballistic missile programs represent an urgent and unacceptable threat to the United States and our allies. The administration must keep all options on the table.   Furthermore, I support the Trump administration’s strategy of coordinating closely with our allies, strengthening our military capabilities in the region, and making clear to Beijing that it is in China’s interests to utilize all of their available diplomatic and economic leverage to change North Korea’s behavior.

We must better serve the neediest among us. Too often, Washington focuses on inputs instead of outcomes.   Social impact partnerships are an innovative way to help our most vulnerable populations improve their lives through proven programs – and that do so in a fiscally responsible manner.  I'm thrilled we have a bipartisan group who came together to introduce innovative social impact partnership legislation today. This is a big step on a very worthwhile journey to help grow opportunities in our communities.  Check out more on our legislation --> http://bit.ly/2pqUZoG

Tune into my first chaired Senate Foreign Relations Subcommittee hearing. I will speak with Indiana University Professor Dr. Una Osili and other experts. Our goal today is to examine the importance of philanthropy in international development.

For 15 minutes on Thursday, Hoosier values will be the talk of the Senate floor. Watch my first floor speech at 10:30 AM live here on Facebook.

Our charge is simple, but it won’t be easy: for our republican system to endure, we must breathe life back into the notion of the “common good” through the relentless application of common sense.   Now, I don’t profess that Hoosiers have a monopoly on the common good. But rather than allowing ideological labels to guide policy making decisions our path on policy, we should instead be guided by what we in Indiana call Hoosier common sense. It’s the notion that we should be guided by the facts, and that we are open to change or new ideas, regardless of ideology, when presented with results.    CLICK to keep reading the entire text from my first speech on the floor of the U.S. Senate...

Some Friday motivation to help get students and parents through these last few weeks of the school year, inspired by this outstanding young lady from Gary, IN.   I think 21st Century Charter School at Gary is gaining a great addition to their team for next year. Congratulations and good luck!
Hoosier CrossFit exemplifies everything that National Small Business Week seeks to recognize. Congratulations on your achievement and we look forward to following your success and community service.

Our team was privileged to welcome some of our great Hoosier Veterans during their #HonorFlight yesterday. Thank you for your service and I hope you enjoyed seeing your memorial! #HonorFlightSouthernIndiana

I delivered my first speech on the floor of the Senate this past week. It took the idea of “Hoosier common sense” and tied it to the mission of working towards the “common good” of Hoosiers and all Americans. Here are eight moments from the speech worth watching again.

The Ethiopian government has indefinitely suspended foreign adoptions, which leaves dozens of near completed and completed adoptions in limbo. The Oren family from Anderson is caught in the middle of this tug of war. They have already begun the attachment process with their son during a visit to Ethiopia. Their adopted son understands that the Oren's are his parents and were confused when they had to say goodbye.   I recently called the Ethiopian Ambassador on behalf of the Orens, and families like them, and appealed to our incoming Deputy Secretary of State to press the Ethiopian government to lift this ban that hurts children and their adoptive families.  Thanks to the Oren family for letting us tell their story, and Kevin Rader and WTHR-TV for helping us shed light on this issue.

Today marks the start of #PoliceWeek. To all of our men and women in blue, thank you for standing on the front lines to protect our communities.  A couple of weeks ago, Senator Donnelly and I introduced the “Law Enforcement Mental Health and Wellness Act”. This legislation is for you.   This bill works with the relevant federal agencies, mental health providers, and broader law enforcement community to offer opportunities for care.   When our police force is healthy and strong, our communities are healthy and strong too.  This bill has received bipartisan support in Congress and widespread support from several law enforcement organizations.   We are all with you.   Thank you to our law enforcement officials for always answering the call. Stay safe and enjoy all the of the just recognition you will receive this week.
Trine University Class of 2017:  1. Remember our happiness is linked to each other's happiness.  2. Always know where the closest Taco Bell is.
‪Happy #MothersDay to all the Moms being celebrated today, especially my wife Jenny who does it all for our family. ‬

This one is for our men and women in blue...  The bipartisan proposal Senator Joe Donnelly and I worked on to improve mental health care access for our law enforcement officers just passed the Senate! When our police force is healthy and strong, our communities are healthy and strong too.

I'm speaking on the floor about the bipartisan proposal Senator Joe Donnelly and I passed through the Senate to improve mental health care access for our law enforcement officers.   When our police force is healthy and strong, our communities are healthy and strong too.

Our veterans deserve to know that they will receive the best care and treatment available when they utilize the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs   Between 2014 and 2016, the Roudebush VA Medical Center lost nearly $1.5 million in medical equipment. This situation is unacceptable and proves that increased transparency, accountability, and reform is needed at the VA.
Hoosier Huddle: 11/07/17

As part of National Police Week, I visited the Indiana Law Enforcement Academy and was able to take target practice at the firing range.   I was also thrilled to meet with the  Greenwood Police Department, Martinsville Police Department, and the Morgan County Sheriff's Office and thank them for their work in strengthening our communities.
Had the pleasure of dining with Vice President Mike Pence, Karen Pence, and the Indiana Congressional Delegation last night. I enjoy working with each of these Hoosier public servants.

It was my privilege and an honor to meet with - and offer my thanks to - dozens of our Hoosier Veterans at the National World War II Memorial today. It was the first stop in a full day of exploring THEIR memorials. Thank you and safe travels today!  Indy Honor Flight

The heroin epidemic has put increased strain on our adoption system. My goal is to remove barriers that prevent foster children from getting placed into long-term and loving homes.   Today, I reintroduced a proposal to modernize our placement system and speed long-term placement of foster children.   You can read more on why we worked on this proposal from an article in the News and Tribune published last year.

Today, we remember the men and women in uniform who paid the ultimate sacrifice while defending and spreading freedom. We will do our best to honor your service always and offer thanks to all of our service members - and your families - every chance we get.   At 3:00 today, join all Americans in a National moment of rememberance to honor America's fallen, and their families. #memorialday
Met many wonderful, patriotic Hoosiers at the Memorial Day service in Fishers this morning. Thank you all.

It was a privilege to present Mr. Paul Wagner, a Veteran and POW of WWII with his overdue medals for service and valor including a Bronze Star.   Thank you for your service and heroism - and to your wife Beverly for always standing by your side.

I've met a lot of great people over the last few days. A school helping students graduate while recovering from addiction, medical device makers employing thousands in Kosciusko County, a Wabash small business wrestling with rising health insurance costs, and a program help employ Hoosiers with disabilities to name a few.  We in Congress need to do what we can to make sure the federal government is enabling -- not interfering with -- their ability to make a difference in Indiana.

America is at its best when it models and promotes universal human rights. We should expect the same from the UN Human Rights Council (UNHRC) and its members.   Ambassador Haley is right to hold the Council accountable, and I look forward to working with her to press for needed Council reforms.     You can read my op-ed on the UN Human Rights Council and Ambassador Haley's efforts below.

For nearly 100 years, hand raisers across Central Indiana have teamed up with United Way of Central Indiana to fight for our neighbors in need. Congratulations on 100 years of service and thanks for all you do to help every person in our communities. #uwci100

June 6, 1944: Brave Americans and our allies stormed the beaches on #DDay and fought successfully to liberate a continent from the Nazis. In a radio address, President Roosevelt asked America to join him in a prayer for the 160,000 allied troops who were about to descend on the beaches of Normandy.

Last night, the Senate passed measures to increase accountability at the Department of Veterans Affairs in order to ultimately improve the quality of care for vets. Providing quality healthcare for our veterans starts with demanding accountability at the VA. This development will help ensure the VA prioritizes quality care and robust accountability so we can avoid further problems like the ones seen recently at the Indianapolis and Peru VA medical centers.

For almost two months, I have pushed the Saudi government to take steps to help alleviate humanitarian suffering in Yemen—where seven million people are at risk of famine.   The Saudis have not been responsive, and the humanitarian conditions there have only grown worse.  That is why I am voting today to oppose the transfer of specific defense articles to Saudi Arabia.   I am not generally opposed to arms transfers, but I also believe that American support should never be unconditional. It is in our national security interests and is consistent with the universal humanitarian values we profess to demand that the Saudis take steps to alleviate suffering that the UN calls the largest humanitarian crisis in the world. http://bit.ly/2soxI90

A common-sense bill to reform how the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs can hold people to account is heading to the President's desk!   Today the House of Representatives approved an already Senate-passed measure to increase accountability at the VA. Our veterans deserve far better treatment than they've received - when bad actors compromise that service, those in charge need the ability to fire them.   This measure is part of an ongoing effort to revamp the VA and I am glad to see that it passed with strong bipartisan support.

This has been a very difficult morning for our Capitol Hill family. Having served in the House of Representatives for six years, my first thought when I heard the news this morning was concern for my friends, former colleagues, police officers, and everyone in the area at that time.  I am relieved to learn that the injured, including Congressman Steve Scalise, will be okay and I thank God for the quick and heroic actions of the Capitol Hill Police officers. They will be getting a few extra handshakes from me today and I know many others will be doing the same.  Everyone involved remains in my prayers, but I leave you with this message: I encourage all of us to be kind to one another; I think we could all use a little more kindness these days

Keller, Jason, Geoffrey and Ryun are four outstanding young men from Warsaw, Indiana. They used their research, writing, and acting skills to tell the story of Pearl Harbor for a National History Day project.  Their hard work and dedication over several months earned them a first place award in the Indiana State competition and an opportunity to compete in the national competition this past week at the University of Maryland, nearby.   In recognition of their achievements, I was honored to recognize their work and accomplishment in the official congressional record of Congress and present it to them at this week's #HoosierHuddle. They reported history and now, they are a part of it.   Congratulations to them and their sponsor and parents. It was a privilege to meet you all.
Welcome home, Genene!

This is further evidence that USA Gymnastics needs to change, and it needs to change substantially and immediately. This pattern of abuse and the resulting lack of accountability at the organization betrays the trust parents put into USA Gymnastics to protect and nurture their children.   We are working through numerous proposals to implement increased accountability measures and significant reforms to ensure this never happens again.

Lise Pace’s son is leaving for his first deployment with the 82nd Airborne out of Fort Bragg, N.C. soon. She stopped by my office for a meeting on an entirely separate issue, but when she asked if I could give him a call, it was my privilege to oblige.  To the men and women of the 82nd Airborne Division: I wish you a successful mission and a safe return; you – and your families – will be in our prayers.

Happy 4th of July to you and your family. This is a day to celebrate our liberties, our freedom, our shared values, and our country. Thank you to the men and women in uniform who have defended these cherished gifts these past 241 years.

The July 3 Naturalization Ceremony held by Judge Sarah Evans Barker at the Benjamin Harrison Home is a beautiful event. Watching 97 new Americans take their Oath of Allegiance was a great reminder of what a privilege it is to be an American.

Mission meets opportunity at Purposeful Design, and it is leaving a lasting impact on the men and women who craft these awesome pieces and in our community, as well. We are honored to have this Hoosier-crafted table in our office and will be proud to share its story with all of our guests.

Our state has done some incredible path-breaking work with respect to addressing human trafficking. It’s really regarded, I think, by many states, as a national model. The Indiana Protection for Abused and Trafficked Humans Taskforce (IPATH) has been an ongoing initiative to study the problem and come up with a way to address it in partnership with stakeholders in Indiana.

This is the story behind the table that they crafted and is now displayed in the Washington D.C. office. I will be proud to share its story with our visitors.  "We're not just trying to create skilled craftsmen. We also want to reach into the heart..." What a great mission at Purposeful Design.

Road trips are a proud American tradition, and the Recreational Vehicles (RV) that many families use for these great excursions are a renowned Hoosier product.  More than 80% of all RVs are made in our great state. From engineering to manufacturing, Hoosier RVs keep Americans safe and comfortable while they’re out on the open road.  It was a great privilege to join Secretary Zinke and the Outdoor Recreation Industry Roundtable (ORIR), including RV industry representatives, to discuss opportunities for improved collaboration to drive investment in the recreation sector and improve Americans’ access to our treasured natural resources.

My thoughts go out to the family and friends of Chief Waters in addition to the entire IMPD News community.

I was proud to vote today in favor of important bipartisan sanctions targeting Iran, North Korea, and Russia—which represent three of the greatest threats to America and our allies. It is important for Congress to focus on protecting the American people and exercising our appropriate Constitutional role with respect to national security.    I look forward to monitoring the implementation of these sanctions and working with my colleagues from both parties to further protect the American people.

Our new website is live! From helping you navigate an issue with a federal agency to helping you arrange a tour of Washington D.C. monuments, it’s all there. Take a look!  https://www.young.senate.gov/

As our Indiana State Health Commissioner, Dr. Jerome Adams has the experience and has demonstrated the necessary leadership to promote the public health and bring awareness to our most pressing public health challenges.   When the opioid epidemic led to an HIV outbreak in Scott County, just one month after Dr. Adams started as State Health Commissioner, he responded quickly, working with our local, state and federal governments, to contain the spread of the disease. His leadership has helped control infection rates and helped to put in place the necessary supports to assist and protect vulnerable Hoosiers.  I will be very proud to vote for his confirmation.

Today, I participated in a classified briefing with Secretary Tillerson and Secretary Mattis.    I continue to believe it’s long past time for Congress to consider and pass an AUMF. Our troops deserve to know Congress supports them.

We had a great group of interns this summer. They all demonstrated a talent and passion for serving our state and a cause greater than themselves. I wish them all the best in – what are sure to be – very bright futures. Swipe through to see a few!  Interested in an internship? Visit our updated website to apply at Young.Senate.Gov today!

I joined CNN New Day to discuss why Congress needs to consider and pass a new authorization for the use of military force.      ISIS and Al Qaeda are still grave threats to Americans, our allies, and our homeland. Congress needs to fulfill its Constitutional responsibility when it comes to an AUMF. Our troops and their families need to know we support them, and our enemies need to know that the American people and their representatives in Congress are committed to defeating the Islamist terrorist threat.  You can watch the full clip here: https://youtu.be/RNpHM19v8HY

The words and actions of Palestinian leaders matter. If leaders are encouraging terrorism and praising those who conduct terrorist acts, it is more likely that additional attacks will occur. Palestinian leaders should stop terror payments and stop praising those who conduct terrorist attacks.  If they fail to do so, U.S. government support for the Palestinian Authority should end.   I am encouraged by the bipartisan support for the Taylor Force Act and look forward to its eventual passage by Congress and implementation by the administration.   The bill is named for Taylor Force, a U.S. citizen and West Point graduate, who was murdered by a Palestinian terrorist.
My statement upon learning of the passing of U.S. Army SGT Jonathon Michael Hunter of Columbus, IN who was killed in action in Afghanistan.

The bipartisan opioid proposal I sponsored with  Senator Maggie Hassan is headed to the president’s desk. This is one step toward ending the scourge of opioid addiction.   The bill will offer doctors better information about the risks of addiction and encourage them to communicate that information with their patients. A simple conversation can have the ability to make a difference in the opioid epidemic that is plaguing communities in Indiana and around the country. That's a conversation worth having.   The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) designates certain opioids as "abuse-deterrent" if they have properties that make it harder to abuse them in certain ways, such as making the pills harder to crush or inject. But these products can still be abused, for example, by swallowing multiple pills. And many abuse-deterrent drugs can still be tampered with to be abused in other ways, as well. Abuse-deterrent drugs contain the same addictive ingredients as opioids in other formulations; however, many health care providers are not made aware of the fact that abuse-deterrent opioids are no less addictive than opioid products without such abuse-deterrent properties.

Those facing life-threatening illnesses should be able to take advantage of unprecedented medical innovation. The Senate passed ‘Right to Try’ legislation that will allow those with life-threatening conditions to access cutting edge medical treatments before they go through the full FDA approval process, as long as they are showing positive results in testing: http://bit.ly/2v4LYUC   The bill was partly named after Jordan McLinn, a boy from Indianapolis, who has Duchenne muscular dystrophy. You can read more about Jordan and his trips to Washington to advocate for this law.
‪The service for City of Southport Indiana Police Department Lt. Aaron Allan was heartbreaking. God bless his family and the men and women who keep us safe every day.‬
This morning I had the opportunity to present Kurt Koch a belated Bronze Star for his service in Vietnam. Thanks to his wife Joyce for arranging the surprise during a staff meeting.

Presenting such an award to such a deserving person is one of the greatest privileges I have as a U.S. Senator. It was an honor to present a very long overdue Bronze Star to Kurt Koch. Thanks to his wife, Joyce, for all of her work to make this happen and pull-off the surprise.

Always a great day at the Indiana State Fair. Thanks to Future Farmers of America for showing us around, U.S. Department of Agriculture Secretary Sonny Perdue for visiting, and to the ag community for sharing your thoughts on the Farm Bill in our roundtable session.
Lutheran Social Services of Indiana is doing great work training and equipping unemployed adults to re-enter the workforce in Fort Wayne. Looking forward to seeing this program grow.

Rode along with IMPD News North District's Officer Labanauskas today. Very impressed with how well the department is connecting with the community and how local churches and organizations like Alliance for Northeast Unification are serving their neighbors.

We just received word that World War II hero, Mr. Paul Wagner has passed away. It was my honor to present five long over-due medals for distinguished service – including the Bronze Star – to Mr. Wagner this past May.   On the day of the ceremony, he recalled that during his time as a POW he thought, “In that moment I thought I was going to die. I was 20 years old, I never did anything real bad, but I never did anything good. What I want to pass on is, I wanted to do something worthwhile before I die." A hero, devoted man of faith and loving husband to his wife of nearly 50 years, Beverly, his life was indeed very worthwhile.   At ease, soldier. Rest in Peace.
The love & compassion I see from Hoosiers every day is far stronger than the hatred on display in #Charlottesville. The former will prevail.‬

Last week, I met Danielle and Kayln, who are recovering from addiction thanks for the folks at Union County Health Department. Currently, the community is pooling resources to address the opioid crisis and help the many people in need, just like these young ladies. This is indeed a national emergency and I support the President’s forthcoming declaration to address this crisis.

On North Korea, we need both a credible threat of military force and vigorous diplomacy.  The credible threat of military force will strengthen our deterrence and empower diplomacy.  That’s why I support efforts to increase military readiness in the region, and why I am so proud of Sec. Tillerson and Amb. Haley who led successful efforts at the UN Security Council to impose robust sanctions against North Korea.   See my full interview from this morning's CNN New Day here: https://youtu.be/Xrszp9Mu5pY?t=5m21s

As a graduate of the United States Naval Academy I can attest that there is a lot of work that goes into the Academy application and nomination process. I will host a series of “Academy Days” informational sessions to help those interested in attending a U.S. Military Service Academy navigate this process. These events are free and are intended for current high school students as well as parents and guardians.  For complete details go to, Young.Senate.gov/help/academy-nominations or call, (317) 226-6700.
Yesterday, I had the chance to visit the Christian Center in Anderson. They are doing great work helping our state's most vulnerable. #OpportunityTour

I spent all day yesterday in Evansville on my #OpportunityTour. Stops included a visit to United Caring Services, a homeless shelter that is helping to reduce hospital recidivism.   I also caught the solar eclipse with Mayor Lloyd Winnecke at Signature School, one of the best high schools in the country.

Interested in attending a Military Service Academy? Our “Academy Days” start today in Ft. Wayne.   Learn more --> https://www.young.senate.gov/newsroom/press-releases/senator-young-to-host-academy-days-for-students-interested-in-attending-us-military-academies

Interested in attending a Military Service Academy? Our “Academy Days” continue today in Franklin.   Learn more --> https://www.young.senate.gov/newsroom/press-releases/senator-young-to-host-academy-days-for-students-interested-in-attending-us-military-academies

Indiana is home to the largest population of Burmese refugees in the U.S. Impressed with the students and leaders I met at Burmese American Community Institute Inc, and I hope to continue working with our Burmese neighbors. #OpportunityTour

Met a great group of future leaders in Franklin last night.  Interested in attending a Military Service Academy? Our “Academy Days” conclude tonight in Evansville.   Learn more --> https://www.young.senate.gov/newsroom/press-releases/senator-young-to-host-academy-days-for-students-interested-in-attending-us-military-academies

The South Shore Line project is critical to job growth and economic activity in northwest Indiana. I am encouraged by the overwhelming support for this investment.   Yesterday, Secretary of Transportation Elaine L. Chao was able to see firsthand the momentum behind this project and all of the involved stakeholders have done a tremendous job of putting together a solid proposal.   I’m looking forward to continue working on economic issues in NW Indiana and the continued progress on South Shore Line.

In Tell City yesterday I met with constituents who encouraged us to continue scaling back regulations that are slowing growth.   Then, in Evansville, students at EVSC (Evansville Vanderburgh School Corporation)'s AIS program that helps students graduate as Certified Nursing Assistants taught me how to properly wash my hands in a medical setting. #OpportunityTour

If we don’t control the cost of healthcare delivery in this country, we are going to continue to see an increase in the cost of health insurance. In our first bipartisan hearing on the way forward for healthcare, I asked witnesses their ideas on how to bend the cost curve down.

I was proud to introduce fellow Hoosier and Notre Dame Law School Professor Amy Coney Barrett at her confirmation hearing to be United States Circuit Judge for the Seventh Circuit. Ms. Barrett is an inspired choice from President Donald J. Trump and will serve with integrity.   Her students have raved about her ability to instill the love for the rule of law in them. And her colleagues have cited her intellect, wisdom, decency, and humanity as to why she will be an extraordinary jurist. I am thrilled she has been chosen for this position and look forward to supporting her moving forward.

I went on Tell Me Something I Don't Know with Stephen J. Dubner to discuss the crazy ways we break election ties in this country and how we can better attack social problems. It’s time for us to embrace a results-driven approach where data and innovation are driving our efforts.
Thank you to President Eisgruber, speaking up in defense of religious freedom as Senate weighs confirmation of Indiana's standout judicial nominee Amy Coney Barrett to serve on US Court of Appeals.
America will never back down or cede our values in the face of terror. Please stop and reflect to remember those who died on this tragic day in 2001.

I'm happy so many Hoosiers were able to join us this morning for another #HoosierHuddle! Thank you for speaking with me about the issues that mean the most to you & so many in our state. Swipe through to see some friendly faces!

It was a pleasure to have the American Legion stop by as we continue our effort to honor their achievements and advocacy on behalf of veterans. Proceeds from the sale of a new commemorative coin will go toward supporting American Legion programs and efforts to continue their invaluable work on behalf of our nation's veterans and their families.

Saudi Arabia is an important regional security partner, but we must not allow food or medicine to be used as weapons of war. The actions of the Saudis in Yemen undercut our national security interests and our moral values—exacerbating the world’s largest humanitarian crisis.   Saudi Arabia can and must do more to alleviate mass suffering in Yemen.
Today I proudly teamed up with the Indiana National Guard in efforts to clear abandoned and blighted homes in Gary, Indiana.

One of my first stops as a senator was touring Gary with Mayor Karen Freeman-Wilson looking for ways the federal government could help the city. When she showed me abandoned structures, we connected the city to the Indiana National Guard to restart a program that hadn’t been used in 17 years. This is the result of people working together. Credit to the National Guard for springing to action and clearing these problem properties.

Indiana has produced more steel than any other state every year since the mid-1970s. Spent a couple hours at U.S. Steel in Gary Friday to talk to the men and women working hard to produce the steel that builds America.

I’m glad Vice President Mike Pence will be in Indiana today to highlight the need to reform and simplify the American tax code.   As I travel the state and talk to everyday Hoosiers, it is clear to me that simplifying our tax code would greatly benefit our economy, boost job growth, and help the American people.

I've been intently focused on these so-called distressed communities since taking office, making several visits to learn how policy makers can better serve the hard-working Hoosiers who live there.    Ultimately, every American deserves the opportunity to better the lives of their families and themselves. I will continue to focus on developing solutions through the help of local community leaders on the ground, in order to create opportunity, and help every Hoosier thrive. #OpportunityTour
Congratulations to Indiana’s Principal of the Year, Nathan Boyd! Educators like you are an irreplaceable part of our kids’ lives.
This morning, I joined WISH-TV Daybreak to discuss a fairer and simpler tax code that will create jobs and unleash growth.

When you get time with the President, you have to make the most of it. I pitched our rail projects in Northwest Indiana. The South Shore Rail Line and the West Lake Corridor are critical parts of future economic growth in the region, and Republicans and Democrats at all levels of government are rowing in the same direction.

I had the opportunity to bring some Hoosier snacks to my colleagues, today. Thanks to the talented men and women at South Bend Chocolate Company; Not Just Popcorn in Edinburgh; Cardinal Spirits in Bloomington; and Schimpff's Confectionery in Jeffersonville. Your treats were a big hit, and I was thrilled to be able to show off our state’s products.
No room for racism and intolerance in the United States military or in our country.  Well said, General.

I spoke with Neil Cavuto on Fox Business about the need for tax reform. The framework proposed this week will help those of modest means get a leg up and will help Hoosier manufacturers be more competitive in a global economy.

Hoosiers can’t wait 17 years for best practices for treatment and prevention of opioid abuse to be implemented. Those best practices need to be implemented far more quickly so those who need access to them can get access to them in order to put them on a better path forward.
I was in studio, this morning, with WANE-TV NewsChannel 15 to talk tax reform and combating the opioid crisis.
I had a great morning recognizing  The American Legion National Headquarters & the newly signed Coin Bill. Proud of their continued work to improve the lives of veterans.

I spent most of the day today at Purdue University. I spoke with students about the successes they've seen through the Back A Boiler program, met with amazing faculty working to feed the world, and discussed how we can expand the innovative work at the Purdue Institute for Drug Discovery.   We are proud to have such a great asset right here in Indiana.

Enjoyed my visit to NHK Seating which is the second largest employer in Frankfort. Thanks to Mayor Chris McBarnes, Brandt Hershman, and Representative Heath VanNatter for joining me as we discuss how to support employers like this across Indiana.

Met with Veterans Administration officials in Indianapolis today to get to the bottom of dozens of claims that have been under appeal for over five years. I was able to call one veteran after the meeting to tell him his claim was resolved. I hope many more will follow.

On Friday, after inviting him to visit earlier this year, I was proud to host the Commandant of the USMC at Crane Naval Surface Warfare Center and Crane Army Ammunition Activity.  General Neller was incredibly impressed by the skilled workforce at Crane and all they do for the Marine Corps, the Department of Defense, and our national security.    Senator Joe Donnelly, Rep. Larry Bucshon, and I welcomed him to Crane and joined him for briefings on Crane’s important work in the areas of expeditionary warfare, electronic warfare, nuclear security, and ammunition logistics.  The Commandant’s visit will help ensure that Crane and its workforce continue to play an essential role in supporting our warfighters for decades to come.
Enjoyed meeting with Chase, an Indiana business owner & National Roofing Contractors Association member, about how we can best serve Hoosiers in the construction workforce.

Currently, seniors who miss the sign-up deadline for Medicare Part B face onerous penalties that persist for the rest of their lives. That’s why U.S. Senator Bob Casey and I today introduced a proposal that will make the sign-up process more efficient and fair for Indiana seniors.   Learn more here: http://bit.ly/2yzOOTc

Wishing Indiana’s growing Hindu and Sikh communities a happy Diwali. The “Festival of Lights” signifies good triumphing over evil, and is celebrated around the world by many people of diverse faiths and backgrounds.

#ICYMI Last week it was my honor to host General Neller, Commandant of the United States Marine Corps, at Crane in Indiana. General Neller was impress by Crane’s skilled workforce and all they do for the Marine Corps, the Department of Defense, and our national security. Burma’s military has conducted a brutal campaign of ethnic cleaning that has displaced over 500,000 Rohingya Muslims.  I just sent a bipartisan letter with 20 of my Senate colleagues to UN Ambassador Nikki Haley urging tangible action to help the Burmese people and hold the Burmese military accountable. We must make clear that there will be consequences for those who commit such atrocities against civilians.

Hoosiers cherish our coastline along Lake Michigan and our proximity to all of the Great Lakes. The Great Lakes are one of America's greatest natural resources and are a vital segment of Indiana’s economic infrastructure. As a Vice Chair of the Great Lakes Task Force, I am pleased Senators from across the aisle came together to urge funding for the Great Lakes Restoration Initiative in next year’s budget.

Today, I delivered a speech on the Senate floor calling for an end to the Burmese military’s systematic campaign of ethnic cleansing against the Rohingya Muslim minority. With thousands of Burmese-Americans living in Indiana, this humanitarian crisis hits especially close to home.   Now is the time to take bold and effective action against the Burmese government to end the violence, not just to help the Burmese people, but to help stabilize the region and protect U.S. national security interests.
Glad to meet w/ @medicaldevices to discuss how the medical device tax is a burden to medical innovation & job creation within the state.
Enjoyed meeting w/ Butler University's President Dr. James Danko about the University’s commitment to student success.

Religious freedom is a fundamental principle of our democracy and a universal human right. Promoting and defending international religious freedom furthers American values and interests and should be an important priority in American foreign policy. That’s why I signed this bipartisan letter today to Secretary Tillerson:  http://bit.ly/2yaDxtW

TANF is an important program for families in need, but the bureaucratic structure of our government’s welfare programs is inefficient and burdensome. Individuals shouldn’t have to meet with different sets of caseworkers at different offices to have the same conversations.  Rep. Jackie Walorski and I came up with a solution that will improve coordination between programs and allow for recipients to spend more time finding work than sitting in a caseworker’s office.
Joining Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and religious liberty groups at 4PM to support Amy Barrett for 7th Circuit Court of Appeals: goo.gl/j9v8Tm

Distinguished Notre Dame legal scholar, former clerk for Justice Scalia, mother of seven children – Professor Amy Barrett is a highly qualified judicial nominee for the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. Unfortunately, some on the left have made issue not of Professor Barrett’s legal qualifications, but of her Catholic faith. We do not have religious tests for office in the United States of America. Period.

Indiana is a prime location for Amazon.com’s upcoming investment in a second headquarters. Our state has a robust and talented workforce, an effective transportation infrastructure network, competitive cost-of-living, and a friendly business environment that has allowed Indiana to be the preferred location for a growing number of domestic and foreign businesses.   Senator Joe Donnelly and I wrote a letter to Amazon detailing our strong support for Indiana’s proposal to be Amazon’s next home. The resulting investment in Indiana would prove that our state is in a position to continue thriving and be a national economic leader.

Professor Barrett is the first Hoosier woman to earn a seat on the 7th Circuit Court, and she makes Indiana proud. https://www.young.senate.gov/newsroom/press-releases/_-young-votes-to-confirm-indianas-amy-barrett-to-7th-circuit-court-of-appeals

Proud to support James Sweeney’s nomination for the Southern District of Indiana District Court. As a Marine, and an attorney in the areas of intellectual property and national security, he has earned broad respect from his peers. He will make an excellent judge in one of the most overworked courts in the country. I urge the Senate to act quickly. goo.gl/VhbsqK

The Times of Northwest Indiana report on my efforts to pass a new #AUMF targeting ISIS is worth reading. Heard from many Hoosiers in Evansville ready for tax reform. Some came with ideas on how to make the package even better. I welcome all input as the Senate crafts its version of the tax reform bill. http://44news.wevv.com/u-s-sen-todd-young-talks-tax-reform-44news-morning/
Joining my colleagues in support of #TaxReform that allows hardworking Americans to keep more of what they earn. Watch live @ 11: goo.gl/iP7e8m

Naval Surface Warfare Center Crane is a national treasure that provides essential support for our warfighters and our national security. After hosting the Commandant of the Marine Corps General Robert Neller at Crane, I wrote a guest column in The Herald-Times highlighting its contributions to America’s national security. Read it here: goo.gl/m8kADi

Enjoyed hosting representatives from Barr-Reeve Elementary School, Maple Elementary School, White Lick Elementary School, Pleasant View Elementary School, and Eden Elementary School in my office yesterday to congratulate them on receiving the U.S. Department of Education’s National Blue Ribbon Schools award. These Indiana schools were recognized as the best of the best, and I’m proud of their hard work.
3.8 million Hoosiers were impacted by the Equifax data breach. I pressed the current and former Equifax CEOs on how they are remedying the situation.
Greatly appreciate the Hoosiers who made the time to join me for coffee & share the issues important to them at this week’s #HoosierHuddle.

Veterans Day is an opportunity to say thank you to all the men and women who have served. I have a strong respect and appreciation for the selfless sacrifices that our veterans and their families have made to protect our great nation. God bless our veterans, and God bless the United States of America.

Hoosiers want a tax code that is simpler, fairer, and allows them keep more of their hard-earned money. Glad to be with Vice President Mike Pence and Secretary Alexander Acosta in Indiana to discuss the need for tax relief.   (Official White House Photo by Joyce Boghosian)
I’m encouraged by the Senate’s tax relief proposal & glad it maintains the adoption tax credit that is important to many Indiana families. I will keep working to ensure Hoosier voices are heard.

This weekend, I spoke with Fox News  Eric Shawn about the need for a new military authorization targeting ISIS & the Senate’s #TaxReform bill that will allow Hoosiers to keep more of their hard-earned money.
Paid tribute to Hoosier veterans at the American Legion Post 18 in Bloomington on Saturday.

William, a maintenance tech from Indiana, dropped by my office this AM to discuss #ApprenticeshipWeek2017. Apprenticeships are a vital resource that can help prepare Hoosiers for high-earning manufacturing jobs of today & tomorrow.
Met with U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs Secretary Shulkin yesterday to push for faster, more efficient claims processing in the VA. http://goo.gl/qjzoVf
For 242 years, the United States Marine Corps has served as guardians of our national security, our interests & our freedom. Honored to join the Marine Corps’ birthday celebration today. #SemperFi

Our bipartisan bill to protect young athletes has passed the Senate. The legislation requires stringent standards for reporting abuse throughout USA Gymnastics & other U.S. Olympic organizations, and holds abusers accountable. goo.gl/5FkurU

I was proud to include language in the FY2018 National Defense Authorization Act that is important to Indiana’s Crane Naval Surface Warfare Center, Pentagon Reform, and Naval Readiness. Learn more: goo.gl/mkWsoQ
Joined WSBT-TV ahead of my visit to South Bend this week to hear what #TaxReform means to Hoosiers.

Tonight’s episode of 60 Minutes will shed light on the humanitarian crisis in Yemen. This week I called for the immediate end of Saudi Arabia’s humanitarian blockade of Yemen that is causing countless preventable deaths, and putting U.S. national security at risk. My statement here: http://bit.ly/2zRa6e2

I’m proud to announce U.S. service academy nominations for 43 exemplary high school senior candidates from across Indiana. These young men and women should be commended for their hard work. goo.gl/kSe4rq
As we give thanks today, I wish all Hoosiers a happy & safe Thanksgiving with your loved ones.

As someone who grew up in a small business family, I know that small businesses are the lifeblood of Indiana’s economy. If we are going to create more small businesses, if we are going to grow more jobs, if we are going to allow Hoosiers and other Americans to keep more of what they earn – We need #TaxReform, and we need it now. #SmallBizSat

I applaud the administration's decision to call the Burmese military's atrocities against the Rohingya what they are: ethnic cleansing. This is an important first step toward holding the perpetrators accountable. That's a big reason why I led a bipartisan letter to UN Ambassador Nikki Haley & helped introduce a bill that would impose targeted sanctions & travel restrictions on senior Burmese military officials. I will continue to do all I can to be responsive to my many constituents and fellow Hoosiers with friends and family in Burma.   More here: https://www.young.senate.gov/newsroom/press-releases/young-helps-introduce-new-sanctions-legislation-targeting-the-burmese-military
Today I visited with the Indiana National Guard who are serving at Fort Meade. These Hoosiers are working to improve our cyber capabilities and keep our country safe. http://goo.gl/9Mssbi
Watch live @ 10:30am as I join Linda McMahon & my Senate colleagues to talk tax relief for Indiana #SmallBiz & job creators like Debbie from Marysville.
My dad always said dream big and work really hard and big things will happen. Shared his advice with Heritage Christian School senior government students today via Skype.

Hard-working Hoosiers want a tax code that is simpler, fairer, and allows them to keep more of their money. Now is the time to take action that will provide relief, boost our economy, and help our small businesses grow.

Wrote a thank you note to our servicemen & women serving overseas this holiday season at the American Red Cross Holiday Mail for Heroes event. There is not enough we can say to thank our troops for their selfless service.

#ICYMI: South Bend businesses share why they need #TaxReform with WNDU. “We haven’t done a real tax reform since I was born. And we’re competing with counties where they make steel, where they get major substitutes from the government, but then also have lower corporate tax rates.”

Tonight the Senate acted on tax reform for the first time in 30 years, and repealed the oppressive individual mandate tax of Obamacare. This is a big win for Hoosiers. Many American workers have not seen a pay raise in a decade. And over 50 percent of American families are living paycheck to paycheck. Repealing the Obamacare tax, doubling the standard deduction, doubling the Child Tax Credit, and lowering rates for middle-income Americans will provide needed relief.

Wrote an op-ed for IndyStar on the Senate’s passage of a #TaxReform package that repeals the Obamacare tax, doubles the standard deduction, doubles the Child Tax Credit, and lowers rates for middle-income Americans. goo.gl/qb7FgR

The Veterans Crisis Line is a critical tool that can help save lives. Like all government programs, we must continue to rigorously evaluate its effectiveness and ensure our veterans are receiving the care they need. That’s why I introduced the Veterans Crisis Line Study Act of 2017, which aims to ensure that the Veterans Crisis Line is effectively serving veterans in distress. https://www.young.senate.gov/newsroom/press-releases/young-donnelly-introduce-bipartisan-bill-directing-va-to-study-veterans-crisis-line

Hoosiers need a raise. Working families need a raise. I can’t think of any better way to do that than providing #TaxRelief.

More than 200 American families remain in heartbreaking adoption limbo trying to bring their children home from Ethiopia.  In order to help, yesterday I led a second bipartisan letter signed by 112 members of Congress urging the Prime Minister of Ethiopia to unite these children with their adoptive families.  Hoping to help welcome home more new Hoosiers very soon!

Visited with Indiana's Naval Reservists for the last drill of 2017. Grateful for their and their families' sacrifice.

Yesterday, I witnessed 97 young men and women graduate from the Hoosier Youth Challenge Academy HYCA. Through hard work and determination, these students got their lives back on track and they should be very proud of what they have accomplished.
On December 11, 1816, Indiana became our nation’s 19th state. Today, we celebrate 201 years of Hoosier values. Happy birthday, Indiana!  #IndianaStatehoodDay

Grateful our office was able to join Senate Committee on Veterans' Affairs to participate in Marine Toys for Tots Foundation collection. Thanks to all those who donated – Your generosity will bring joy to so many families this holiday season.
